bestBHT.bht: The inference is that Zacharias was not only dumb but also deaf, as there would have been no reason for others to make signs if he could hear. They consulted with him through repeated signs, suggesting a loss of hearing. Perhaps his temporary deafness was a punishment to allow for silent reflection. Being the father, it was fitting that he had the authority to name his child in this situation.

Henry Alford: The natural inference (see on ver. 22) from this verse is, that Zacharias was deaf as well as dumb...
...nor do I think that the objectors have succeeded in invalidating this inference.
There could have been no reason for beckoning, had Zacharias been able to hear articulate words.
Marvin Vincent: They made signs [ενενευον] . Imperfect tense. While the colloquy between Elizabeth and her friends was going on, they were consulting Zacharias by signs.
Philip Schaff: They made signs to his father... it would appear that he was deaf also.
Meyer conjectures that they made signs in order to spare the mother, when they referred the case to her husband. But this is a pure assumption.
The punishment inflicted on Zacharias was designed to give him time for silent reflection...
Archibald T. Robertson: Made signs (ενενευον). Imperfect tense, repeated action as usual when making signs."
In Luke 1:22 the verb used of Zacharias is διανευων."
What would he wish him to be called? (if he could speak), a conclusion of the fourth-class condition.
John Gill: Such a method as these took with Zacharias, about the name of his son, is directed to in case of a father's deafness, in relation to knowing who is his firstborn."
Father that is dumb, they search or examine him in the way they search for divorces; if he makes signs, or writes, that this is his firstborn, lo! this takes the double portion.
They were right in applying to him, to whom it most properly belonged, to give a name to his child.
